title: Nmap
description: Using and interpreting Nmap: host discovery, port scanning, service/version detection, OS fingerprinting, NSE scripting, performance/timing, output formats, and common troubleshooting patterns. Use only on networks you own or are authorized to test.

categories.title: Basics and Safety
categories.description: Core concepts, terminology, and a few safe defaults.

items.title: Common scan phases (mental model)
items.description: Most Nmap runs are some combination of: target selection -> host discovery -> port scan -> service detection -> OS detection -> NSE scripts -> reporting.
items.example:
# Conservative baseline (TCP SYN scan + version detection)
# Note: requires privileges for -sS on most OSes
sudo nmap -sS -sV -T3 -oA scan 192.0.2.0/24

items.title: Target notation and files
items.description: Nmap accepts IPs, CIDRs, ranges, hostnames, and files.
items.example:
# List file supports comments (#) and blank lines
cat > targets.txt <<'EOF'
# Web servers
192.0.2.10
192.0.2.11
# Subnet
192.0.2.0/28
EOF

nmap -iL targets.txt

items.title: Privileges and what changes
items.description: Some scan types require raw sockets/privileges.
items.example:
# If you can't run privileged scans, use -sT
nmap -sT -sV 192.0.2.10

categories.title: Host Discovery (Find Alive Hosts)
categories.description: Separate host discovery from port scanning; choose probes that match the environment.

items.title: Ping scan (-sn)
items.description: Host discovery only (no port scan).

rows: Discover alive hosts using default probes
TCP SYN ping to chosen ports
TCP ACK ping (helps through some filters)

items.example:
# Local LAN: ARP is best
sudo nmap -sn -PR 192.168.1.0/24

items.title: Skip host discovery (-Pn)
items.description: Treat targets as online (useful when ICMP/pings are blocked).

rows: Scan even if host seems down
Common when only a few ports matter

items.example:
# Typical when firewalls drop ICMP
sudo nmap -Pn -sS -p 22,80,443 192.0.2.10

items.title: Host discovery outputs to expect
items.description: Discovery results differ by method and network conditions.

rows: Probes blocked or hosts truly down

categories.title: Port Scanning Fundamentals
categories.description: Pick scan types by privileges, accuracy needs, and what the environment allows.

items.title: Scan types (TCP/UDP)

rows: Find UDP services; slower; interpret carefully
Firewall rule/state mapping (not for open ports)

items.example:
# Common combos
sudo nmap -sS -p 1-1000 192.0.2.10
sudo nmap -sU --top-ports 50 192.0.2.10

items.title: Port selection
items.description: Scanning fewer ports is faster and easier to interpret; scan all ports when needed.
items.example:
# Enumerate all TCP ports first, then do -sV on opens
sudo nmap -sS -p- --open -oA tcp-all 192.0.2.10

items.title: Interpreting port states
items.description: A port can be open, closed, filtered, or variants like open|filtered. Use --reason to see why Nmap decided.

categories.title: Service and Version Detection
categories.description: Identify what’s behind an open port (banner/probing).

items.title: Version detection essentials
items.description: -sV probes services; increase intensity if results are generic.

items.title: Service detection troubleshooting
items.description: If Nmap can’t identify a service reliably, collect more context and cross-check with other tools.

categories.title: OS Detection and Fingerprinting
categories.description: OS fingerprinting works best with at least one open and one closed TCP port.

items.title: OS detection flags
items.description: -O enables OS detection; it may be inaccurate across NAT, load balancers, or filtered paths.

items.title: Traceroute and network distance
items.description: Nmap can run traceroute; useful context for interpreting filtered results.

categories.title: NSE (Nmap Scripting Engine)
categories.description: Scripts for discovery, versioning, auth checks, misconfig checks, and reporting. Keep output; scripts can be chatty.

items.title: Script categories and basics
items.description: NSE scripts are grouped by category (safe, default, discovery, auth, vuln, intrusive, etc.).
items.example:
# Default scripts + version detection
sudo nmap -sS -sV -sC -p 80,443 192.0.2.10

items.title: Common NSE patterns
items.description: Use script expressions to focus on safe/discovery info first.

items.title: Script arguments
items.description: Many scripts accept credentials, paths, ports, or app-specific parameters.
items.example:
# Example only: check script docs for valid args
nmap --script-help http-enum

categories.title: Performance, Timing, and Reliability
categories.description: Balance speed vs accuracy; avoid melting networks or triggering rate limits.

items.title: Timing templates (-T0..-T5)
items.description: Higher is faster/noisier; lower is slower/stealthier and more reliable on fragile networks.

items.title: Rate/parallelism controls
items.description: Useful when scanning large ranges or fragile links.
items.example:
# Keep a scan gentle
sudo nmap -sS -p 1-1024 -T2 --max-rate 200 --max-retries 2 192.0.2.0/24

items.title: Fragmentation, decoys, and spoofing (why to be careful)
items.description: These options exist, but can be unreliable and are often inappropriate outside controlled testing; they may violate policy/law. Prefer correctness and authorization.
items.example:
# Prefer documenting results instead of evasion tricks
sudo nmap -sS -sV --reason -oA scan 192.0.2.10

categories.title: Output, Reporting, and Parsing
categories.description: Save results in more than one format; automation is easier with XML/grepable output.

items.title: Output formats
items.description: Use -oA for all common formats at once.

items.title: Verbosity and debugging
items.description: Increase verbosity before you jump to packet traces.

items.title: Grepping quick wins
items.description: Useful when you have lots of outputs.

categories.title: Common Workflows (Examples)
categories.description: Practical sequences that produce useful results with reasonable effort.

items.title: Discover -> scan open ports -> detect services
items.description: A high-signal workflow for a subnet.

rows: sudo nmap -sS -sV -p $(awk -F'[ /]' '/open/{print $1}' tcp.gnmap | cut -d: -f2 | sort -n | uniq | paste -sd,) -iL <(grep -E '^Host: ' discover.gnmap | awk '{print $2}') -oA svc

items.example: # Note: process substitution requires bash; otherwise write host list to a file.

items.title: Quick single-host triage
items.description: Fast, high-signal scan for a single host.

categories.title: Command Structure and Targeting
categories.description: How Nmap commands are composed: targets, ports, scan types, output, and common modifiers.

items.title: General syntax
items.description: Nmap typically follows: nmap [Scan Type(s)] [Options] {target specification}.

items.title: Port specification tips
items.description: Explicit port selection improves speed and interpretability.

items.title: Name resolution controls
items.description: DNS resolution can slow scans; disable if you only need IPs.

categories.title: IPv6
categories.description: Scanning IPv6 targets and common considerations.

items.title: IPv6 basics
items.description: Use -6 to enable IPv6. Discovery differs from IPv4; local link can use neighbor discovery.

rows: Local link discovery (interface scope syntax varies)

items.title: Dual-stack workflows
items.description: Scan IPv4 and IPv6 separately and keep outputs distinct.
items.example:
sudo nmap -sS -sV -oA host-v4 192.0.2.10
sudo nmap -6 -sS -sV -oA host-v6 2001:db8::1

categories.title: Automation and Scripting
categories.description: Repeatable scanning with files, diffs, and simple shell pipelines (authorized environments only).

items.title: Keep a scan manifest
items.description: In operational environments, record: scope, authorization ticket, command line, timing, and outputs.
items.example:
nmap --version
# store the full command line in a README alongside scan outputs

items.title: Diff scan results over time (ndiff)
items.description: ndiff compares Nmap XML outputs to show changes between runs.
items.example:
# Example: compare weekly scans
ndiff week1.xml week2.xml | less

items.title: Use --open to reduce noise
items.description: For inventories, output only open ports to keep reports concise.

rows: Only open ports across all TCP

categories.title: Tool Suite (Ncat, Nping, Ndiff, Zenmap)
categories.description: Nmap often ships with companion tools for connectivity testing, packet generation, and diffing.

items.title: ncat (connectivity and simple listeners)
items.description: ncat is Netcat-like. Use for authorized connectivity testing and debugging.
items.example:
# Check if a port is reachable
ncat -nv 192.0.2.10 22

items.title: nping (probe and measure)
items.description: nping sends probes for troubleshooting latency/loss and validating firewall paths.

items.title: ndiff (compare scans)
items.description: Compare two Nmap XML files and report differences.

items.title: Zenmap (GUI)
items.description: Zenmap is a GUI frontend for Nmap (availability depends on OS packages).

categories.title: Troubleshooting and Common Errors
categories.description: Common failure modes, what they usually mean, and how to proceed safely.

items.title: Host seems down
items.description: If discovery probes are blocked, Nmap may report hosts as down.

rows: Confirm firewall policy and scan scope

items.title: Need privileges (raw sockets)
items.description: Some scan types require elevated privileges.

rows: Run with sudo or switch to -sT

items.title: Unreliable results (timeouts/rate limits)
items.description: Back off timing when dealing with WAN links, rate-limited devices, or IDS/IPS.

rows: Use --reason and traceroute; confirm firewall behavior
